Award.AwardTitle: CRISP Type 2/Collaborative Research: Probabilistic Resilience Assessment of Interdependent Systems (PRAISys)

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
After a disruptive extreme event, such as an earthquake or severe storm, the socio-economic recovery of the affected region depends on the recovery of its infrastructure systems. Lifelines, such as power and water distribution systems, transportation networks, communication systems, and critical buildings have a primary role in disaster response, management, and long-term recovery. The failure to rapidly restore the services required for personal, social, and commercial activities leads to continued socio-economic losses and progressive depopulation. This collaborative project brings together scholars in Civil Engineering, Systems Engineering, Computer Science, Economics, Urban Planning, and Policy Making. Its purpose is to establish and demonstrate a comprehensive framework that combines models of individual infrastructure systems with models of their interdependencies for the assessment of interdependent infrastructure system resilience for extreme events under uncertainty. The "PRAISys" platform (Probabilistic Resilience Assessment of Interdependent Systems) will emphasize a probabilistic approach that permeates all aspects of the models, including the interdependencies. Some types of uncertainties that were not considered before (e.g., the possibility of using contingency plans that provide services without functioning infrastructure) will be classified; while mathematical and computational tools will be devised to capture their characteristics. PRAISys will enable better management and design of next generation infrastructure, more resilient to extreme events and to component failures under normal conditions. This will reduce the likelihood of extreme events becoming catastrophic in terms of casualties and injuries, long-lasting socio-economic losses, and environmental impact. The results of the research will be disseminated to the public in various forms: through series of seminars for professionals and administrators; by participating in Lehigh University's STAR academy program for disadvantaged middle and high school students; through scientific publications and presentation; and by curriculum development.

The development, calibration, and validation of PRAISys will enable research on stochastic interdependencies among infrastructure systems in the wake of an extreme event. This requires advancements in several disciplines. For instance, a new hybrid reliability model, which combines graph theory for network analysis and classic system reliability to model the probabilistic dependencies among infrastructures will be studied. The new concept of "uncertain dependencies," which are rigorously modeled and include "contingency plans" will be introduced. Advancements in stochastic network optimization will be sought, to predict the optimal strategies and to inform the disaster management. Social network data will be used as an additional source of information on the recovery of a region, in real time, mining public posts. A comprehensive decision framework will combine the results of the simulation platform with expert opinions and surveys to identify the importance of various aspects of recovery. Finally, new techniques for the collection of large sets of data from utility companies, local government and other authorities will be studied.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall goal of this collaborative project involving Florida Atlantic University, Lehigh University, and Georgia State University (CMMI #1541089 and CMMI #1541177) is to develop a computational platform that is capable of addressing uncertainties in infrastructure interdependencies after a catastrophic event. The computational platform called “PRAISys”, which stands for “Probabilistic Resilience Assessment of Interdependent Systems,” simulates the interdependencies between three types of infrastructure systems: transportation, communication, and power. Interacting with all infrastructure sectors and influencing their degree of interdependence is the socio-economic environment, which we consider a fourth system. Interacting with all infrastructure sectors and influencing their degree of interdependence is the socio-economic environment, which we consider a fourth system. The latter refer to the social science component of the project which seeks to understand how infrastructure breakdowns affect the socio-economic system and how restoration priorities are determined.

Our contribution to this collaborative award focused on how socio-economic factors interact with the infrastructure systems to strengthen or weaken community resilience. Specifically, our contributions centered on three aspects of the platform development: (1) how public and private stakeholders such as emergency managers, city planners, utility providers, and other decision-makers establish priorities with regard to service restoration; (2) the impact of cumulative and interdependent infrastructure breakdowns on household and community recovery; and (3) providing GIS data for the three testbeds embedded in the computational platform. In the platform itself, these three aspects are combined in a comprehensive decision framework which includes expert opinions and surveys to determine weighting factors.

Significant outcomes include:

In our analysis of socioeconomic vulnerability and electric power restoration timelines in Florida after Hurricane Irma,  we found that: (i) rural counties, predominantly served by rural electric cooperatives and municipally-owned utilities, experienced longer power outages and much slower and uneven restoration; (ii) there is a strong relationship between the duration of the power outages and the type of electricity provider; (iii) the percentage of customers served by cooperatives and municipally-owned utilities is a strong predictor of the duration of extended power outages. Additionally, three socio-economic variables (minority groups, people with disabilities and unemployed) were found to be statistically significant highlight three different aspects of vulnerability to power outages.

We used log-linear models to analyze key interdependencies between emergency services sector (ESS) and critical support services. The results indicate several levels of complex interactions between ESS and power, fuel supply, water, transportation, and communications. The results also indicate that service disruptions can result from disruptions in critical upstream infrastructures and regional scale infrastructure failures as well as from local scale service interruptions with local and regional impacts (Mitsova et al., 2020)

A logit model was estimated based on  household survey responses to analyze the associations between a self-reported recovery status and a set of predictor variables including: structural damage to the place of residence, duration of infrastructure disruptions; disruption of medical services or access to medications; race, ethnicity, age, income, housing tenure/ homeownership, insurance, and language spoken. We found that physical damage to property, disruption of infrastructure services such as loss of electric power and cell phone/internet services, and other factors (i.e. homeowner’s or renter’s insurance coverage, receiving disaster assistance, and loss of income) are significant predictors of post-disaster recovery when controlling for age and race/ethnicity (Mitsova et al. 2019, Mitsova et al. 2020)

Our research has also made methodological contributions in survey data analysis. In recent years, there has been an exponential growth of the number of studies using nonprobability online surveys.  Although allowing for an easy data collection, these studies are often criticized for not meeting the rigor of the traditional randomized sampling. Based on recent advances in survey research, we developed a methodology for combining probability and nonprobability samples using propensity scores estimation and matching techniques (for more details, refer to Mitsova, Esnard, Sapat, Lamadrid, Escaleras, and Velardez-Perez, 2020).  

In terms of spatial data analysis, we estimated the extent of disrupted electric utility infrastructure in the Florida Panhandle following Hurricane Michael using both county-level power outage data and NASA’s Visible Infrared Imaging Radiometer Suite (VIIRS) Day/Nigh Band (DNB). Additionally, we obtained the 2013-2017 American Community Survey estimates at the block group level to downscale the percent loss of electrical service to a neighborhood level. Finally, we examined the effect of socio-economic variables on service loss and recovery using autoregressive spatial lag models with percent recovery and the rate of recovery as the dependent variable. Our preliminary results indicate that the longest power outage duration was observed in the rural Calhoun and Jackson counties, followed by Bay and Gulf counties that experienced a direct hit by the hurricane. The results also reveal an uneven distribution of service loss and disparities in power restoration within each county. Our results indicate that big data acquired through satellite imagery can provide high-quality, scalable, and timely information on power outage.
